Let $a_1,$ $a_2,$ $\dots,$ $a_{12}$ be real numbers such that $a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_{12} = 1.$  Find the minimum value of
\[a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \dots + a_{12}^2.\]
inference:
Without loss of generality, assume $a_1\ge a_2\ge\dots\ge a_{12}.$
Note that $(a_1+a_2)^2\le a_1^2+a_2^2.$
Thus,
\begin{align*}
a_1^2+a_2^2+\dots+a_{12}^2&\le (a_1+a_2)^2+(a_3+a_4)^2+\dots+(a_{11}+a_{12})^2\\
&\le(a_1+a_2+\dots+a_6)^2+(a_7+\dots+a_{12})^2\\
&\le(a_1+\dots+a_6)^2+(a_7+\dots+a_{12})^2\\
&\le(1/2)^2+(1/2)^2=\boxed{1/2}.
\end{align*}
Final Answer: $\boxed{1/2}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
By Cauchy-Schwarz,
\[(1^2 + 1^2 + \dots + 1^2)(a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \dots + a_{12}^2) \ge (a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_{12})^2,\]so
\[a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \dots + a_{12}^2 \ge \frac{1}{12}.\]Equality occurs when $a_i = \frac{1}{12}$ for all $i,$ so the minimum value is $\boxed{\frac{1}{12}}.$
